channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: China, Needing Babies, Eases Limits on Births
item.description: A number of new incentives encouraging people to have children highlight the challenges China faces in trying to boost its declining birthrate.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman and her child on a street in Shanghai.

item.title: War in Ukraine Has Changed Europe Forever
item.description: No event has transformed the continent more profoundly since the end of the Cold War, and there is no going back now.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian travelers arriving at the Vaalimaa border crossing between Finland and Russia. Its emptiness speaks of new European division.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Nears U.K.-E.U. Deal on Brexit’s Northern Ireland Protocol
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is expected to meet on Monday in Britain with the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, to work out the final details.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ferry arriving last year in Northern Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom but has an open land border with Ireland, a member of the European Union.

item.title: Tempered in a Crucible of Violence, Zelensky Rises to the Moment
item.description: In much of the world, President Volodymyr Zelensky, once brushed off as a political lightweight, has become a household name, representing Ukraine’s tenacity and underdog victories against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kherson, Ukraine, in November. As the war has progressed, Mr. Zelensky, 45, has grown more confident and battle-tested.

item.title: In Nigeria’s Presidential Election, A Rare Chance to Turn the Corner
item.description: In Nigeria’s presidential election on Saturday, voters were desperate to elect a leader who can unleash their youthful country’s potential and chart a new course after years of dashed hopes.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign rally for Peter Obi, the Labour Party presidential candidate, this month at Alaba market in Lagos, Nigeria. Some polls have shown him in the lead of a wide-open contest.

item.title: Their Hair Long and Flowing or in Ponytails, Women in Iran Flaunt Their Locks
item.description: Defiant resistance to Iran’s mandatory hijab law has exploded across the country after nationwide protests that erupted last year.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman, sans head covering, at the Tajrish Bazaar in Tehran last month.

item.title: A NATO Minnow Reels From Cyberattacks Linked to Iran
item.description: Albania has been the target of repeated digital assaults believed to be linked to its sheltering of an Iranian dissident group on its soil.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tirana, the Albanian capital, in January. Cyberattacks have swept Albania, a Balkan nation with fewer than three million people, into a maelstrom of uncertainty.

item.title: A Year of Russia’s War on Ukraine Is Marked by Protests and Defiance
item.description: On the anniversary of the invasion, Volodymyr Zelensky held a marathon news conference and vowed victory if Ukraine’s allies remained united like a fist.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Chyrinska lights candles for those who died in the Church of Andrew the First in Bucha, on Friday.

item.title: After Model’s Gruesome Killing, Suspicion Falls on Ex-Husband and His Family
item.description: Abby Choi, known for her glamorous Instagram posts, was reported missing on Wednesday. On Friday, the Hong Kong police found her remains, dismembered and incomplete.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: The police standing guard on Sunday outside the building in Hong Kong where the remains of Abby Choi were found.

item.title: Russia, Ukraine and the West Vow to Fight On, in a War With No End in Sight
item.description: Moscow and Kyiv face daunting challenges in moving forward, with no clear sense of what an attainable victory might look like.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners in Bucha on Friday visiting the graves of Ukrainian soldiers who died fighting in the war.

item.title: 10 Years After Lac-Mégantic Tragedy, Are Canada’s Rails Safe?
item.description: When a runaway train loaded with oil jumped the tracks in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, 47 people died in Canada’s worst rail disaster in nearly 150 years.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the devastating 2013 train derailment, known locally as “the tragedy,” in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec.

item.title: Earthquake Hardships Pile Up in Turkey: Shattered Homes and Lurking Disease
item.description: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in tents, breathing air thick with pollutants unleashed from tombs of rubble, fearful that a new disaster could strike at any moment.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Nimet Kirac
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sahutoglu family’s collapsed house in Samandag, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: Nigerian Politician Arrested With Nearly $500,000 on Eve of Election, Police Say
item.description: For years, Nigerian politicians have been accused of buying votes. The lawmaker, the police say, was caught with dollar bills and a list of possible recipients.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Workers helped load electoral materials into a truck from the Central Bank in Yola, Nigeria, on Thursday. Voters are preparing to head to the polls on Saturday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Race to Encourage Births
item.description: Also, how the war in Ukraine changed Europe and Iranian women are removing their hijabs.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children playing at a park in Shanghai.

item.title: Large Crowds Across Mexico Protest Overhaul of Election Watchdog
item.description: Demonstrations took place in over 100 cities against the recent overhaul of the country’s electoral watchdog, which officials say could make fair and free elections difficult.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of people gathered on Sunday in Mexico City’s main square to protest against the overhaul of the electoral watchdog by the governing party.

item.title: Russian Diaspora Finds Ways to Protest Putin’s War
item.description: From Berlin to Chicago, crowds gathered to express solidarity with Ukraine and to underscore that not all Russians support Vladimir Putin’s war.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A vigil against Russia’s war in Ukraine was held near the Russian Embassy in Washington on Friday, the anniversary of the conflict.

item.title: West Bank Attack Kills 2 Israelis as Middle East Officials Meet in Jordan
item.description: A Palestinian gunman killed two Israelis as American, Israeli and Arab officials met to discuss ways to lower tensions. Then Jewish settlers went on a rampage.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli security members standing guard at a main junction close to where Israeli police officials said two Israelis were killed near Nablus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Sunday.

item.title: Dozens Drown as Migrant Boat Breaks Up Near Italian Beach
item.description: High waves and strong winds dashed a wooden boat against rocks on the coast of Calabria, in southern Italy, killing at least 59 migrants.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Rescuers recovering bodies on the beach of Steccato di Cutro, Italy, on Sunday.

item.title: Kung Fu Nuns of Nepal Smash Convention
item.description: In Himalayan Buddhism, the religious roles of nuns have long been restricted by rules and customs. But one sect is changing that, mixing meditation with martial arts and environmental activism.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Saumya Khandelwal

item.title: Child Labor Today
item.description: A Times exposé has revealed that young teenagers work long shifts, sometimes for nationally known brands. What can be done?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrant children in Roma, Texas.

item.title: Deadly Russian Artillery Strikes Reported in Ukraine’s East and South
item.description: Officials said at least five civilians were killed in the attacks, as President Vladimir V. Putin repeated his claim that the war is part of a U.S.-led effort to destroy Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donbas region of the country firing a howitzer at enemy positions earlier this month.

item.title: In Ukraine War, Talking About Peace Is a Fight of Its Own
item.description: Russia and the West have argued for months about which side is more willing to negotiate, with the world as an audience.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Talk of reopening negotiations is intended to placate allies, cast the opposition as unreasonable and, especially on the Ukrainian side, tamp down a growing desire within Western countries to find an end to the costly war.

item.title: Shinta Ratri, Fighter for Transgender Rights in Indonesia, Dies at 60
item.description: The Islamic boarding school she helped found offers a haven for transgender women in a country where discrimination can be acute.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Shinta Ratri in 2022. She founded Pesantren Waria al-Fatah in 2008 with two colleagues as a retreat for transgender women and a place for them to pray.

item.title: China to Welcome Belarusian Leader, Raising Concerns Over Ukraine
item.description: A state visit next week by Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus comes as the U.S. has accused China of preparing to send lethal aid to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in 2016. Their aides say they will be talking about trade and investment in a coming meeting, but analysts say Ukraine will be high on the agenda.

item.title: War in Ukraine Deepens Divide Among Major Economies at G20 Gathering
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen urged her counterparts at a summit in India to condemn Russia’s actions, and she defended the cost of supplying aid to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Janet L. Yellen in Bengaluru, India, this past week. “Ukraine is fighting not only for their country, but for the preservation of democracy and peaceful conditions in Europe,” she said in an interview.

item.title: Getting Back on Skis
item.description: Returning to activities you’ve given up can be a surprising source of confidence and wonder.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: For the First Time in 52 Years, There’s No Skating Through the Capital
item.description: A winter of gyrating temperatures and rainfalls caused officials to give up on the “world’s largest skating rink.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Rideau Canal Skateway on Thursday, the night before officials abandoned plans to open it.

item.title: The Salton Sea, an Accident of History, Faces a New Water Crisis
item.description: The vast California lake relies on runoff from cropland to avoid disappearing. But as farmers face water cuts due to drought and an ever drier Colorado River, the Salton Sea stands to lose again.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Mette Lampcov
item.media:description: A dock that once extended onto the Salton Sea, the state’s largest lake, now looks out on a dusty, desert-like vista.

item.title: Biden Reaffirms Support for Ukraine Amid Concerns About Russia-Iran Ties
item.description: The Biden administration announced new measures targeting Moscow and supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin’s war.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden speaking in Warsaw on Tuesday. “Ukraine will never be a victory for Russia,” he wrote on Twitter. “Never.”

item.title: Robert Hébras, Last Survivor of a 1944 Massacre in France, Dies at 97
item.description: Dead bodies shielded him as the Nazis killed 643 people in Oradour-sur-Glane. He spent his life keeping the memory of the slaughter alive.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Robert Hebrás, in 2011, in the original French village of Oradour, which was burned in 1944. The ruins are now a memorial.

item.title: Doctor Denounces C.I.A. Practice of ‘Rectal Feeding’ of Prisoners
item.description: In a hearing at Guantánamo Bay, an expert gave a graphic public depiction of torture after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Dr. Sondra S. Crosby, an expert on torture and trauma, testifying in a Connecticut court in 2009. “This was a very, very distressing painful, shameful stigmatizing event,” she said of the C.I.A. torture practice.

item.title: 5 New(ish) Australasian Books for Your Reading List
item.description: Great reads you might have missed.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Outside Readings bookstore in Carlton, Australia, this month.

item.title: China Reprises Old Themes in Ukraine Plan, Casting Itself as Neutral
item.description: A year after Russia’s invasion, Beijing released a paper declaring its position on the war: It called for an end to the fighting but avoided demands that could hurt its ties with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Steven Erlanger and Edward Wong
item.media:description: China delivered a paper stating its position on the war in Ukraine, but it was not the bold initiative that some in Europe expected after a speech by China’s most senior diplomat, Wang Yi, last week in Munich.

item.title: Zelensky Answers Reporters’ Questions for Over 2 Hours
item.description: On the anniversary of Russia’s full-scale invasion, Mr. Zelensky offered a broad overview of where the war stood, the challenges Ukraine faced and the opportunities in the months ahead.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: “I am confident we will have this victory and hope it will happen this year,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Friday.

item.title: BASF to Cut 2,600 Jobs After a Year of High Energy Costs
item.description: The German chemical giant blamed a drop in profits on stubbornly high natural gas prices and shifting global demand.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: BASF said on Friday that earnings last year dropped 11.5 percent from the year before.

item.title: What I’m Watching, Weimar Noir Edition
item.description: “Babylon Berlin” is the TV show I can’t stop thinking about.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A poster for “Babylon Berlin” in Berlin.

item.title: U.S. Eyes Trade Deals With Allies to Ease Clash Over Electric Car Subsidies
item.description: The Biden administration has faced backlash in Europe and Asia over its plans to bolster electric vehicle and battery production.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s top finance official, with Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen in Bengaluru, India, on Friday. Top European officials have expressed their concerns about the Inflation Reduction Act to Ms. Yellen and other Biden administration officials.

item.title: Ireland Cheers Paul Mescal for Embracing Irish Language
item.description: On the red carpet for the British Academy Film Awards, the Oscar-nominated actor gave an interview in Ireland’s national language.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: Paul Mescal at the British Academy Film Awards at the Royal Festival Hall in London. He spoke Irish during a red carpet interview, inspiring a conversation about use of the national language of Ireland.

item.title: Six Ways the War in Ukraine Changed the World
item.description: The ripple effects of Russia’s invasion have reordered lives and upended economies. Here are some of the consequences.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A barley field in Odesa, Ukraine, in June.

item.title: A United Front
item.description: Western unity could have consequences beyond Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military volunteers at a weapons storage facility in Fastiv, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: The Times invites readers to reflect on the war in Ukraine.
item.description: Share your reactions and observations about the conflict.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The French Like Protesting, but This Frenchman May Like It the Most
item.description: Jean-Baptiste Reddé has hoisted his giant, colorful signs in nearly every street protest for over a decade, embodying France’s enduring passion for demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-Baptiste Reddé with one of his traditional posters last month. He was on his way to a demonstration in Paris against the French government’s proposed pension overhaul.

item.title: New York Times Photographers in Ukraine on the Images They Can’t Forget
item.description: In a year of war, New York Times photographers have reported from the front line, from cities and villages and in the footsteps of refugees. These pictures stayed with them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: ‘It’s Complicated’: How Biden and Zelensky Forged a Wartime Partnership
item.description: The relationship between the two leaders has become critical to the future of the international order.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was 13 when his country emerged from the collapsing Soviet Union as an independent country.

item.title: Kidnappings in Nigeria and Other Security Crises Concern Voters Ahead of Election
item.description: Nigerian voters say that insecurity is the most important issue in this week’s presidential election. One man who was kidnapped said, “You can only survive on your own in Nigeria.”
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olusola Olaniyi, 63, was kidnapped in February 2021 while running a digging site for a farm on the outskirts of Ibadan, Nigeria.

item.title: Mystery Sphere on Japanese Beach Was Just a Buoy, Experts Say
item.description: Experts said the sphere that washed ashore, leading to speculation about espionage, was nothing special. “Maybe everybody is paranoid because of balloons,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno, Mike Ives and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The world’s most famous buoy, on a beach in Hamamatsu, Japan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Yellen Confronts Russian Officials at G20 Meeting
item.description: In a private session, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said the Russians were “complicit in Putin’s atrocities,” according to remarks shared by a U.S. official.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen at the meeting of Group of 20 finance ministers in Bengaluru, India, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The war in Ukraine, one year in.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Boris Johnson outside Downing Street, in London, last month.

item.title: The U.S. Intelligence Playbook to Expose Russia’s Ukraine War Plans
item.description: Bolder disclosures are part of a larger effort to stymie the Kremlin’s offensive in Ukraine and align support for Kyiv’s war effort in allied countries.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.media:description: President Biden and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at a news conference in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: After A Year of War, Ukrainians Have Learned How to Judge Lethal Threats
item.description: After a year of war, people in Ukraine have become adept at telling which threats are probably not deadly, leaving room for a little enjoyment, and even hope.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents rode in a trolley through Kyiv on Thursday. The service has reopened after Russian bombardment forced it to shut down.

item.title: Photos: Shows of Solidarity With Ukraine Around the World
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: U.S. Sends Home Brothers Held for Nearly 20 Years at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The latest release, of two Pakistanis never charged with a crime, reduced the detainee population of the once-sprawling prison complex to 32.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: A 2013 picture of Mohammed Ahmed Ghulam Rabbani, left, and Abdul Rahim Ghulam Rabbani at Guantánamo Bay provided by the legal defense organization Reprieve.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Year of War
item.description: Also, Nigeria’s upcoming election and health. care protests in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers placed sandbags to reinforce a checkpoint in Kyiv, Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Wagner Leader’s Feud With Russia’s Military Leaves Questions About War Effort
item.description: The leader of Wagner appears to have backed down from his latest criticism of Russia’s senior command. But his vitriolic remarks suggested more discord in Russia’s war effort.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Russian newspaper Kommersant showing Yevgeny Prigozhin, holding a hat and flowers, at a ceremony for one of his fighters in Volgograd, Russia, last year.

item.title: French Student to Be Charged With Premeditated Murder in Teacher’s Stabbing
item.description: Prosecutors painted a portrait of a troubled, socially awkward teenager who had been bullied, and who attempted suicide in October.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: St. Thomas d’Aquin in St-Jean-de-Luz, France, has a reputation for academic excellence.

item.title: Ukraine Uses Strikes on Mariupol to Suggest It Now Has Longer-Range Weapons
item.description: Ukraine has used attack drones to hit relatively distant targets, but the new strikes paired with comments from a Ukrainian official stirred speculation that Kyiv may have acquired a new weapon.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: Tom Whitlock, Co-Writer of ‘Top Gun’ Anthem ‘Danger Zone,’ Dies at 68
item.description: Mr. Whitlock wrote the words for that song and the chart-topping “Take My Breath Away,” central elements in the success of the hit 1986 movie.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Giorgio Moroder, left, and Tom Whitlock posing with their Oscars at the 59th annual Academy Awards in Los Angeles in 1987. “Take My Breath Away,” which they wrote for the movie “Top Gun,” was named best original song.

item.title: Wind and Solar Energy Projects Risk Overwhelming America’s Antiquated Electrical Grids
item.description: An explosion in proposed clean energy ventures has overwhelmed the system for connecting new power sources to homes and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Walker Pickering for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pouring concrete for a wind turbine in Nebraska. More than 8,100 energy projects were waiting for permission to connect to electric grids at the end of 2021.
